getCollectionTypeOfField

public static java.lang.Class<?> getCollectionTypeOfField(java.lang.reflect.Field field)
Finds the type of elements of a Field that declares a Collection. Bad input returns null. If the field is not parameterized, Object is returned.
An assumption is made that the field declaration contains only one type argument.
Disclaimer: This will not work for a declarations like StringList foo; //StringList extends List.

Parameters:
field -
Returns:
The type of the collection elements declared with this Field.

findTypeParameter

public static java.lang.Class<?> findTypeParameter(java.lang.Class<?> type,
                                                   java.lang.Class<?> baseParameterizedType,
                                                   java.lang.Class<?> baseParameterType)
Finds the parameter argument existing somewhere in a types hierarchy. The extra input required for this to work is worth the trouble, as it is certain that the correct result is fetched and not some random parameterized type argument.
For example assume that we are searching for the type argument <T> of a A<T> sub-type. The concrete parameter could be declared anywhere in the hierarchy, but always in a sub-type of A. Invoking this method with
baseParameterizedType: A.class
will result to the search of all super-types that are a sub-type of A, up to and including A, closest to the class specified by the type argument first. On this search path we are guaranteed to find the correct type parameter argument.
Note that parameters that are ParameterizedType are not returned. For instance searching a sub-type of A<T<S>> will not return the type argument T<S>

Parameters:
type - Type we inspect.
baseParameterizedType - Super type of type that is a ParameterizedType and has the parameter we search for.
baseParameterType - Expected class of the parameter. The parameter must be a sub-type of this. If this is null, it is ignored.
Returns:
Returns the parameters
